Some of the most iconic moments in the history
of cinema come from pairing the right piece
of music with the right scene.

And often, when doing this correctly, it becomes
so ingrained in our minds that we can no longer
separate the two.

Think of Kubrick's use of "Also Sprach Zarathustra"
in 2001: A Space Odyssey.

Or Coppola's use of "Ride of the Valkyries"
in Apocalypse Now.

These moments are elevated to something beyond
what each individual component can offer on
their own.

After all, that's what movies are all about;
with exception to TV or video games, film

is the only medium of art that can combine
music with visuals in this way, and there

are few filmmakers that can match Quentin
Tarantino when it comes to choosing the right
soundtrack to fit a scene.

"It's a big part of what I do, I think it's
um...it's a big part of the fun of modern

movies - of modern cinema and when I say modern,
I mean to some degree starting with Rock Around

the Clock played in Blackboard Jungle, and
now it's very normal to have modern pop songs
in your films."

"And not only are they in them, you kind of
cut the scenes to them.

When you do it right, and the music and the
movie kind of goes in sync with each other,

for a sequence or so, it's just kind of like
you're flying or you're skating or something."

The right blend of visuals and music can serve
as a tool for character development, giving

us a glimpse into a character's personality
based on the music they listen to.

Or it can be used to help establish the setting
and the atmosphere surrounding that time and
place.

Through use of both diagetic and non-diagetic
music, often borrowed by classic films that

inspired him; the unique personality of each
of his films is reflected in the soundtrack.

Sometimes the choice is an obvious one, like
the title track for "Django Unchained" that

was lifted from the Sergio Corbucci film "Django",
or borrowing a track from the 1973 Pam Grier

cult classic "Coffy" for a scene in "Jackie
Brown"; but I think some of his best choices

aren't always immediately obvious, like the
use of Charles Bernstein's score from the
film "White Lightning" in "Inglourious Basterds".

" But then there's the opening theme song
to "White Lightning" and I just remember that

opening, was just very, very, very haunting
and I thought it was terrific and I go...

hey, that could be...not a theme for the Bastereds
per se, but something that would be really

interesting to show them doing their thing,
and play this twangy, country, haunting theme

in the middle of a WWII movie that takes place
in France.

I thought was a neat thing, it brings the
American-ness, it kind of almost acts as an

echoing theme for Aldo because he's from the
South.

There's a sinister quality to that theme from
"White Lightning", and I like the fact that

there's a sinister quality underscoring the
Basterds and what they do."

One of the things that Tarantino is known
for is his ability to blend genres and tones
seamlessly.

Whether that's creating a Spaghetti Western
set during WWII or combining a slasher flick

with the classic car movies of the 1970's,
he always finds a way to mash together tones

and styles that you don't normally see in
the same movie.

One of the reasons that his genre blending
works so well is his use of soundtrack; to

dictate the emotions that he wants you to
feel.

"I feel like I'm the orchestra conductor and
the audience's reaction are my orchestra.

The sounds you make are my instruments, your
feelings are my instruments; so it's like:
Laugh.
Laugh.
Laugh.
STOP laughing.
Stop laughing.
Okay, now be horrified.

Be horrified, this is horrible, this is horrible...this
is horrible...horrible...horibble...laugh."
"English motherf***er do you speak it?"

Being able to manipulate the emotions of his
audience, particularly through these tonal

shifts aided by the film's soundtrack; is
what made him famous even all the way back
with his very first film, "Reservoir Dogs".

"The music in the movie, part of that comes
from the fact that in America we have a lot

of oldie's stations, and what they'll constantly
have like every other weekend or something,

they'll have like a special weekend: a Motown
weekend, or a British invasion weekend, and

so I came up with the idea that since the
movie takes place in the course of a very

short time period, that it takes place while
they're having a Super Seventies Weekend so
they're playing all this 70's music.
And again, it manages two things for one thing.

For most of the movie the goofiness of the
song kind of like you know, an intense movie

like this, it kind of lightens it up a little
bit.

It kind of gives it a little bit of a jab,
a little wink, and it's kind of cool and it
makes it kind of fun, alright.

But, like in the 'infamous torture scene'
that everyone and their brother is talking

about, the use of the song 'Stuck in the Middle
With You' which is like this bouncy kind of

cool song, alright, not only does it not make
not lighten up the scene, it makes the scene
even harder to watch.

Because you're sitting there and you're watching
and all of a sudden this tune comes on and

you're like oh yeah, da-da-da, the guitar's
playing, kind of tapping your toes it's catchy
and Michael starts doing his little dance.

I defy anyone to watch Michael do his little
dance and not get a kick out of it because

he's just having a blast you know, and then
BOOM.
The hard stuff starts."

"You're sitting there watching it that but
it's too late, you're already a co-conspirator,

you enjoyed the song, you enjoyed the dance,
now you gotta take the hard stuff."

It's the sort of creative choice that would
never occur to most people to make, but once

seeing it in the film I defy anyone to argue
that it wasn't the perfect song to fit that
scene.

Which is exactly what a film soundtrack should
be, something that fits so perfectly you couldn't
imagine any other piece of music in its place.

All too often in films or television I find
that the music isn't really doing anything,

it's just sort of there to add some sort of
background pulse to a scene, even when the

scene would work just as well without any
music, and sometimes a scene works better
precisely because it doesn't have any music.

In every Tarantino film to date, he manages
to find the perfect balance; knowing exactly

when and when not to use music, and when he
does use music he always finds the perfect
track.

Quentin Tarantino is widely known for his
encylopedic knowledge of films, having seen

thousands of films from every era, country,
genre; and by all accounts his knowledge of
music isn't far behind.

And I think that's how he always knows exactly
which song will fit any given scene.

He keeps mental notes of all of his favorite
film scores, or his favorite pop songs and

when the opportunity arises he puts them to
good use.

"There's always songs and pieces of music
or songs that you hear over the course of
time and think 'Oh!

This would be a good driving song.' for some
movie.

Or 'this would be a good dance song' for some
movie; for an opening credits sequence, this

would be great for a closing credits sequence,
this would be great for an entrance like what
you're talking about.

The thing is I hear these things and then
they're just in the back of my mind as far

as like, okay, look for an opening for those,
one of these days, and so whenever I come

up with a story and I start diving into my
record collection, trying to find the beat

or the rhythm of my movie and then I just
start diving into it more like research until
I start finding stuff."

Instead of just throwing something in after
the fact; often an entire scene is written,
shot, and edited with that song in mind.

Giving us some of the most iconic and memorable
scenes of his career.

Because, in Tarantino's own words:
"When you put the right piece of music with

the right scene, the right sequence; then
I actually truly think it's maybe the most
cinematic thing you can do."
